poem:
**On the Matter of Hyphens and Deliveries**

In the kingdom of nouns, a hyphen  
is but a slender bridge—  
yet Andrew, heir to the hyphen,  
becomes a dashed line  
in royal annals.  
Meanwhile, verbs move like carriages,  
deliver promises to doorsteps,  
and Rachel, ledger-bound,  
waits by the gate,  
purse open, tallying the cost  
of each verbose journey.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Question raised by ex-prince’s hyphen | Brief letters Is the restoration of the hyphen to Andrew’s name confirmation that he is a dashed nuisance to the royal family (Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor’s name to be hyphenated, as decreed by late queen, 12 November)?Claude ScottRichmond, London • If each inappropriate use of the word “deliver” were taxed (Starmer allies issue warning to PM’s rivals as fears grow over leadership challenge, 11 November), Rachel Reeves would have her money. “Deliver”". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
